The market is a dynamic phenomenon. Therefore, if there are extraordinary profits in a sector, the entrepreneurs' own desire to earn more money will cause prices to stabilize again. And when there is too much supply, the incentive to invest in that sector will gradually disappear until a balance is achieved. Setting minimum and maximum prices cause instability, misinformation and scarcity, government intervention in strategic sectors generates inefficiency and can end up harming some people in favor of others by force.

I find this video to be a very shallow argument in favor of capitalism, for the following reasons:

Your simulation has no mechanism for one seller to have to close shop from a lack of sales, which in reality is what happens as one competitor eventually consolidates and corners a local market. From here the "law" of supply and demand becomes completely divorced from reality as the monopoly will benefit from economies of scale and will be able to put other competitors out of business who simply cannot compete. Once the monopoly has no more competition in the town, they are free to set prices to whatever they like and consumers are forced to deal or go without.

This also applies to housing, where no matter how much housing is available, the market will naturally tend toward consolidation as we see with the housing markets in the US and the UK. It's not as if there is a lack of supply; we have enough housing to house every homeless person if we so desired. It's just that the system inherently favors those who have capital and are able to make that investment, while regular folks have trouble even getting their foot in the door for even the highest interest rate loans. And so the landlords get richer while everyone else suffers

Your core premise is also faulty outside of luxury goods and hobbyist markets. If you need to buy food, you will pay for what is available. It doesn't matter if you wanted to pay $20 for a week of groceries because ultimately you have to eat and the alternative is starving. The same applies to healthcare, where big pharma will charge ridiculous prices for life saving medicine for no other reason besides that they can, and they make so much profit anyways that it doesn't matter if most people aren't willing to pay for that.

Market economies might appear good on paper but your simulation does not account for anything resembling reality. Please do better.

The end of the video is wrong. The intervention only causes dissatisfaction. If people need food, then they buy food instead of other things. If there is not enough food for everyone, then there is not enough food for everyone and intervention cannot fix that.

The end of the video is confusing because it makes the viewer think that there are literally people who don't eat in the free market. The graph for the necessary products is not the same, and is adjusted to the price of the last seller. Obviously, if a person has to eat, their criteria for buying food is not the same as for buying a movie ticket.

When people have more than one need, for example food, clothing and shelter, then there are three graphs and people prioritize by need.

In addition, the interventional technique does not take into account that the market is a dynamic scenario. If you make the final adjustment, you destroy the profit margin and with it the motivation of entrepreneurs to continue producing or investing to produce more precisely of that good that is scarce, so the next time you will have more poverty of that good instead of more wealth.

Your blobs here didn't choose their price, either for selling or for buying. There is also no other industry for them to take part in. It's a shame that this is dealt with a hand wave of 'they can go find another market somewhere to take part in', when the reality of how people end up in their socio-economic situations both from a businesses and a personal standpoint isn't far off. The blobs here who had their business fail or simply couldn't afford to buy rockets were left by the wayside, there was no other option for them. Their fate was sealed.


Since the greatest indicators of success for any person is generational wealth, I would ask why we assume that people are so different from these blobs, and somehow able to determine their own futures. Anecdotes of success exist, but it's disappointing to find such a huge issue with the market system simply hand waved.

Its a good model, but it can fall short in certain aspects (disclaimer, im a consumer, not an economist), like when we account for "unfaithful competition" and monopolies, or when crisis/inequality (either internal or external) leads to an excessive play of a certain "player" (be it banks, tourism, foreing investors, etc) and markets like real estate gets screwed (because its tied to a lot of other stuff, including employment and infrastructure, so is not that easy to correct it) or like when an industry like mining requires chips that are not in THAT much surpluss and the market cannot adjust in time
Interestingly here in Argentina you can see them all... you can see real estate at an abnormally high price, tied to the USD and limited by the inability of consumers to buy a house, you get excesive intervention (like price control) that leads to bankruptcy and loss of quality /employees (which further affects the market), you get imported goods heavily taxed on top of the local devaluation and ebcause the prices cannot go lower at all (taxes cant be waived and costs are not local) it creates a two-layered crisis, and... well, its a mess, but is definitely interesting, like, only a select portion of the market with very specific criteria can compete in a real free market, and others are victims of excessive as well as lack of intervention. Crazy, huh?

The reality is that free market should always be a thing, but regulations should be there to allow that equilibrium as well. Specially in certain stuff like real estate or basic products and services like electricity, medicine and food. Specially since, even when a particular market is in red numbers (either actually red or when it comes to potential earnings comparatively) if it strengthen all the other markets, its actually a net positive. A perfect example would be a good welfare system in a welfare state, which, creating a solid "floor" from which they cannot fall even if they wanted to, and still not having (at least a hard one) cap/ceiling economically, citizens are more likely to invest or get educated or start their own business and even if they fail, which they are not afraid anymore, the market moves and so does money. Eventually, at least in theory, those in need of welfare would decrease as the amount of it increases (even more solid floor) which is more likely to decrease the remaining people in need of welfare.. and so on and on until you probably get into an equilibrium (no system is perfect). Another example would be employers increasing the net salary of their employees, and as such as it happened at the end of last century in the US if im not mistaken, theres more and more people with money to spend and willing to. Same with time as well (more time and energy to spend the money at hand) etc etc, so we could say that a market in a vacuum works one way but a nation is way more complicated and needs to account for interlacing (interlocking? sorry for bad english) factors like opportunity, foreign agents and minimum standard of living.

I do feel that the rich can be beneficial to good and cheap products. A case in point.

-- I remember when DVD players first became available, the first model was about $2,000. A fad for the rich to own - that is being first. Now because they spent $2,000 (It might have been $1,000 but it was sure very expensive to me in 1993) on that DVD player, their voices are louder when it had original design bugs or flaws. This forced the manufacturers or designers to work those bugs out because those rich people were also very vocal when something went wrong.

As they ironed out the bugs and made it more cheaper to produce - it became more cheaper to mass produce so the common people could then afford to buy them. All thanks to the rich people being the first to own it status symbol. Not always the case - but it something I believed back in 1993 when I saw my first DVD player in a shop window as I walked home from high school. I thought "let the rich people buy it first - because they get all the flaws and we get the better product". I still have this attitude to this day - wait a few years when something new comes out, because by the time I get to it, it will be cheaper and hopefully not as flawed or dangerous. - This is my view and I hope I didn't rock the boat with it.

This is, as i assume is intended, a very narrow scoped video. And can as such come off very idealistic.

Mostly because it assumes a few things which are rarely true in the real world.

1. People can freely choose not to buy/sell, this is obviously not true for things like healthcare, food and housing

2. That the surplus the sellers gain and the surplus buyers gain are equally valuable. In the real world the surplus gained by the buyers gains them nothing (in the end they either have a rocket or not, regardless of what they paid for it)
Whereas the surplus gained by the sellers could be used to buy something else

3. That sellers and buyers can't change type, and that you can't be both types.
Sellers selling rockets for higher than average could become buyers with the surplus they gained, and buy up all the rockets to get even more surplus.

As someone who has run a computer sales and repair company for a few years now, my motto is "Undercut your competition just enough to draw their customers to you, while maintaining a positive seller-seller relationship for networking purposes. Never sell something for what you can get, but sell it for what its worth, ensuring that you have a minimum price of the cost of the product, payroll and other business expenses." Using this motto, the only way competition can undercut you is to cut corners on quality, downgrade their business model or eventually go out of business and then you can merge their company's assets into your own. Awesome video! well explained but regulating the market isn't efficient in any case. You can't predict the disruptive innovations and development of knowledge as the evolution of the demand. The regulations are statics but the market is dynamic. The Austrian School, the school of economics which studies dynamic markets, has in it's theory a theorem called the theorem of impossibility of statism. The schools that model the markets like the Keynesian School or the Monetarist School are based in calculations that are incompatible with any accepted capital theory; which sometimes make them a good tool in the short-term but they are useless in the medium- and long-term. Unfortunately these models are used as an excuse by some governments to expend more money than they should

The "argument" for govt interference in certain markets completely ignores the overall impact of that action. The only way for govt to do that is to either subsidize a commodity or to limit the price. Subsidies come out of taxpayer pockets. So there's an involuntary expense that effects how much surplus people have to put towards other things. Which effects what they're willing to pay in other markets. Price ceilings force companies to inflate prices elsewhere in order to make up the loss. Again, this effects the surplus buyers have available to spend on other markets. There can also be other consequences that aren't immediately apparent. For instance, the federal govt maintains a sugar cartel in the US. There are regulations about who can produce sugar, how much sugar can be produced, and the minimum price sugar is allowed to sell for. The end result being that the price of sugar is artificially inflated. But people want cheap sweets. So manufacturers had to find an alternative. Conveniently, the govt also subsidizes corn. This makes high fructose corn syrup much more affordable than sugar. And that's why it's used in most drinks and sweet foods instead of sugar. The bottom line is that central planning can never beat a free market because no planning committee can possibly react as quickly and as effectively as "the invisible hand". It's literally the difference between serial and parallel processing.

Also, we had excellent access to health care prior to govt intervention. Look up "lodge medicine". Not "medicine lodges", that's a different thing. Back in the day people joined fraternal lodges, like the "Elks" and such, for more than just social events. Their monthly dues also paid to keep a doctor on retainer. So lodge members had quicker access and discounted prices for the doctor's services. And the doctor got a level of guaranteed income. But the AMA felt it was wrong for educated, well-heeled people like doctors to be at the beck and call of the riff-raff from the mills. So they lobbied against lodge medicine and got it banned. As a result of govt "saving" us from such a decrepit practice, the AMA now has monopoly control over health care in the US. They decide what qualifies as "medicine", what institutes get to teach medicine, even how many doctors are allowed to be taught every year. If you're going to cite health care as a broken market, you should at least be honest about why it's broken. It isn't a free market.

Economic models have a very hard time modeling entrepreneurship because it deals with the value of time, risk, and uncertainty. Methodologically, some would argue modeling the development of new industries and their effect on existing ones is actually impossible. Because such things can't be predicted, our ape brains tend to leap toward coercion solutions (government) to peaceful problems, where the most optimal solution is actually entrepreneurial.

Importantly, we have to remember what constitutes an efficient market and what state intervention implies. A market needs many buyers and sellers on the margin to dynamically work it toward equilibrium; a state is a compulsory monopoly thus there is no tangible negative feedback mechanism to nudge it's behaviors back towards optimal when it misbehaves hence government programs are often in or cause crises.

Freedom to transact and voluntary participation is something governments allegedly exist to enforce by rule of law and rights yet they can also prohibit, mandate, and control entire markets to our detriment. Where markets in a suboptimal condition will signal through prices and our choices to change things, governments may only be informed by popular sentiment which may differ greatly from the values evidenced by our actions.

Good information, in particular relevant information, can only come from people taking various actions. These actions manifest as price signals as to whether a certain supply chain is configured well or poorly yielding profits or losses, or whether a given industry should grow or contract. Hayek proposed the knowledge problem of central planning contending that even the best intentioned state actors couldn't optimally plan an economy because they simply know too little about what they're planning.

There may very well be some value in making sure everyone can eat, earn money etc.
But artificial intervention in any ecosystem always has disastrous effects.
First of all we must assume the intentions of government are honest and good. Then we must assume that it is possible to truly look at the whole market, at everyone, and get a good intuitive understanding of it as a whole.

People have been arguing for decades whether we should be engaging in weather modification, climate engineering and geo engineering to lesser the effects of climate change, yet we never end up pursuing any one option because most people agree we do not truly have a good understanding of what the potential side effects may be. We all tend to agree that the burden of proof lies on the one making the proposal to artificially influence the natural ecosystem, even though unlike with economies, we already have been artificially influencing climate.

Yet when it comes to politics we make decisions on the basis of what policies sound like and what their assumed goal seems to be, rather than considering consequences we may not be able to predict and laying the burden of proof on the person making the proposal for artificial intervention.
A good argument has never been truly made for it, policies just get pushed through by politicians voted for by people who vote with their hearts, stomachs, ears and never their heads.

11:09 Yes, exactly. It doesn't make sense to apply economics to survival since continuing to exist has demand approaching infinite.
However, even if these requires us to apply a little socialism, state socialism isn't the only option. The opposite end of the socialism pole is libertarian socialism.

What I particularly like about it is that is decentralizes (or distributes) power away from the top (i.e., from federal government to local citizens councils as well as from international corporations to local co-ops) without requiring violent revolution. For example a consumer co-op can compete in the market with a corporate retail store. Since the corporation's bottom line is profit for investors and since the consumer co-op's bottom line is whatever its members want (and the members are the investors, so presumably they have specifically invested in a consumer co-op [as opposed to investing in a corporation] to create access to better quality goods or services) then they are competing with similar, but ultimately different products. This means a consumer co-op will never lead to things like planned obsolescence because the members aren't trying to get one over on their customers because their customers are themselves.

This also means that there's direct democracy for those who are interested and representative democracy for those who aren't. For example, as a member of a credit union (basically the co-op version of a bank) I have the ability to attend meetings and vote on issues. But, I have no interest in the bureaucracy of banking. Some of my peers do, though, so when they attend such meetings they in effect act as my representative. This works because our both being members of the same credit union means that our interests are aligned within that context. In this way we can either have representatives or be representatives for others in as many organizations as we are involved. This can also work for various citizens' councils.

Seems to me its a much healthier mix of competition and cooperation without the concentrated power which corrupts both state socialism/communism as well as neoliberalism/capitalism.

I don’t know why but this reminded me of the problem (I forget what it’s called or if it even has an official name) where I have a $100 bill and I open it up for bidding between 2 people starting at $0.01.  So if you bid and win, you get my $100, for just 1 cent. However obviously the other person is going to bid $0.02 because, well hey they aren’t going to miss that 2 cents when they win $100 for it. And so the other person bids it up again. Because until you’re forced to bid $100, you’re making money on the bid. So even if you and the other person bid back and forth all the way up to $100, at the very least you’ll break even then. Except there’s a special rule in this bid war, where the LOSER of the bid, still has to pay 50% of their losing bid. So what this creates, is the 2 people thinking they’ll keep outbidding the other by 1 cent until it reaches $100, as even at $99.99, they’re still making money, yeah it’s just 1 cent, but it’s still a positive. And if it reaches $100, well then they’ll just break even no big deal. But person B places that $100 bid, and now what? Well now person A would be silly to bid $100.01 for a $100 bill as they’d lose $0.01, but in reality, because of the rule where the loser has to pay 50% of their losing bid, if they don’t bid that $100.01, that means they let person B win, and break even, and now person A has to pay 50% of $99.99 or $50. So, don’t bid again, and lose $50, or bid $100.01 to try and win, and only end up losing $0.01? Obviously they’re gonna bid again, even though now they’re bidding more money than the prize is worth because they now want to minimize their loss. Except now person B is on the losing end, and will have to pay 50% of that $100 bid, so are they gonna lost $50 or place a bid for $100.02 and only lose $0.02? They’re gonna bid to reduce their loss. And this continues on and on and on until it reaches a bid of $200, where by winning the bid, you lose $100 because you paid $200 for $100, and the person who lost, pays 50% of $199.99, or $100 and both people lose $100, the person who bid $199.99 isn’t going to then bid $200.01 because then they’re actually only increasing their loss by bidding because now by winning that bid they’re out $100.01 rather than $100, so the seller, easily doubles their $100. Also in this problem the 2 bidders don’t know each other and have no way of communicating with each other to try and talk about a solution such as one person bidding $0.01 and the other letting him win and then splitting the money. Or one person realizing the issue and letting the other person win just so they both don’t end up being out $100 by the end of it. I don’t know why this made me think of that but it did lol

the issue with this is, people believe in the "invisible hand" for markets that don't work at all in these ways, as there are a lot of things that block the invisible hand from working ideally
"many buyers and sellers" & "voluntary participation": if you get a monopoly on a survival-based product, like glasses, you don't have any other sellers but a lot of buyers who can't choose to not buy your product.
"good information" whoever has many can advertise their product better, leading to bad control of information aka no new competitors can enter
"freedom to transact with anyone" this is completely ruined by subscriptions / deals and our internal struggle to remain faithful to what we did before. also, often impeded by "good information" not given.

Video entirely justifies itself by accepting markets as a justification of privately owned production. Without talking about how you get markets, the arguments for and against come down to for or against regulating a market we assume should just exist. In order for markets to exist in this model, the means of production for the sold things must be owned, but they aren't owned in common by people. They're owned privately by individuals or small groups which inevitably use their power of production to consolidate more market power. Instead of looking at that system and saying "we should try to regulate it"—which involves a State entity that needs a monopoly on the legitimate use of violence to enforce—maybe we should just not do that system at all. This is so weirdly out of place for the progression of the series thus-far, that it is borderline an injection of Capitalist ideology directly into Biology at this point. If the workers—who worked to make the things—directly owned the products of their labor and were not alienated from it by those who own the machines they labor on to make the products, then you wouldn't need a market since that system stabilizes on any of two equilibria: the workers create specific things independently or in unions based on what they think they can barter for; or the workers weave themselves into local communities of diverse labor and products, which doesn't require barter since each can know the needs of their neighbors and directly provide and be provided for. Thousands of civilizations and communities like each of these have existed and thrived around the world. Some still exist today. Many were wiped out by foreign invader States who decided workers owning their own means of production was a threat to their awful and selfish system—the one we use today where drug companies can decide who lives and dies because they "own" medicine patents, and the threat of violence from the regulators can't keep up with the rapidly shifting strategies those private owners use to stay ahead of the regulation. Because it turns out, letting a few people consolidate power is a self-reinforcing power consolidation loop that eventually outstrips any threat we can propose a powerful regulator have. Private ownership can grow exponentially. State regulation and punishment can only grow linearly, and largely responds to damage that has already been done after it's too late.

I think this model has some theoretical issues.
There is no such thing as a "maximum price" on the side of the buyers - ore to be more exact: The maximum price is allways determined by the supply.
For example the desire to eat is an essential desire - no matter how much it costs, the buyer would pay any price for something to eat if he is starving otherwise.
We have some of this essential desires: food and drink in the first row. housing, clothing, hygiene and many other things in second row.
So we see there is no way to make up a quantitatively proportion between this desires.

So if we take your first example (one buyer - one seller) and assume an essential desire such as food there is realy no price limit exept the money the buyer has in his pocets. The buyer is completely dempendent of the seller. We could say that the only real limit for the price of the bread in this example is determined by the minimum amount of food the buyer must get for his money to keep him away from starving and repeating the transaction at the next day.
Ore we could assume, that the buyer is working at a factory and gets a wage of for example 40 dollars but he could also cancel his job and produce one bread a day in his own kitchen. In this example the maximum price for the bread would be 40 dollars again. But the only reason for this circumstance is again a matter of supply and not of demand.

Assuming something like a natural maximum prize of the buyer and therefore declare the value to be a subjective cathegory must lead into a wrong economic theory.

In the scenario where buyers outnumber sellers and the prices increase: This is exactly how new businesses get started. As the price rises, it signals to entrepreneurs and investors that there is a lot of demand not being met (e.g., the buyers with the lowest asking price who will eventually leave the market) and they will move resources into that market as long as there is profit to be made. In 1974 the economist Friedrich Hayek won a Nobel Prize for recognizing this important function of prices.

When the sellers outnumber the buyers, and the price steadily declines until a seller goes out of business, that seller’s assets are usually liquidated and turned into cash that someone will invest in another industry where there is more demand (see above). So the “Invisible Hand” works across MULTIPLE markets, steering the entire economy’s resources where they will generate the most value. A free market where that dynamic equilibrium is unrestricted will ALWAYS create the most value in absolute terms, but no two people can ever agree how that value should be maximized in relative terms. You may want to maximize the value for a specific class of citizens, or within the borders of a specific country, or within a specific industry, or within a specific timespan - so most markets are regulated with such goals in mind even though it will make the market less productive in the long run.

Seeing the idea about ways to help make sure that the vast majority of buyers all get to buy the item in demand at prices each of them are willing to pay individually, regardless of market value, all while also making sure that the vast majority of sellers all get to sell the item in demand at prices each of them are willing to sell for individually (to make a profit) reminds me of both a Dutch auction, where the price of the item being auctioned is initially set high, and is gradually lowered until someone is willing to purchase the item at that price, at which point the item is sold to the bidder, and an English auction, where the price of the item being auctioned starts off at a low price, and potential buyers compete to purchase the item by raising the bid, thus raising the item's price to the highest bid, until no other potential buyers are willing to bid for a higher price, in which case, the item is sold to the highest bidder.

Your definition of surplus @1:55 insinuates that in order to have a surplus the seller needs to sell at a higher price than the minimum set. That is wrong as the surplus is incorporated into the value of the product in the form of cost for (accumulation of capital + reproduction of productive capacity to produce said product). This definition of surplus fails to take into account the cost of reproduction into cost, meaning that to sell at minimum would actually lead to loss. Why? Because machines break down and labor costs increase over time.

"Surplus" in general is defined (in economics) as resources left after transaction or transformation, superior to what was utilised or expected, a.k.a. excess (opp: shortage/scarcity): can be excess in cash, production or supply.
Now, there's "Consumer surplus" when the price of a good/service is inferior to the market price or what the consumer expected (how much the consumer was willing to pay); "producer surplus" occurs when the seller's price is below the market price, reflecting how much the seller is willing to accept for given quantity of a good/service, which leads to profit.
Saying straightly that "the surplus is a measure of how worthwile the transactions are" might confuse some people... anyway.

I am quite dissatisfied with this video, as it does indeed accurately simulate neo-classical economics, but completely misses the fact that during the past 50 years there has been absolutely no equilibrium whatsoever. According to these simulations, which are accurate in and of itself, people like Jeff Bezos, Bill Gates, or Mark Zuckerberg cannot be explained, and I find it rather dissatisfying that this is not an issue.

Brand loyalty is only a fallacy. It assumes that what has worked before will continue to. And usually, it would, but the brands change their strategies and production processes, thus changing the product. In an enlightened market, where all the buyers known the pros and cons of every product variation, there shouldn't be any brand loyalty. I have no brand loyalty at all. I go for the greatest surplus that nets me a functioning product. And in the cases I'm enlightened enough, I can take the quality, measured in how long the product will last, and get a greater net surplus.

This video is misleading. If you took this at face value that means half the population of the US starves to death. This is obviously untrue.
In the real world...
First, buyers want to buy more than 1 of each product, but they have an increasing highest price they are willing to pay for each additional purchase. This leads to more buyers buying but not all buying the same amount and more sellers selling.

Second, sellers have different products that provide different amounts of happiness. Buyers want to maximize their happiness but also have a maximum price they will pay for that happiness.
This means people willing to pay more pay more for better products and those willing to pay less buy lower quality products.

I know this is a simplified model, but we still don't know where the costs of acquiring the rockets come from and why it makes sense for some blobs to buy a rocket at a very high price. This looks very static, but is depicted as a dynamic situation, which doens't seem very realistic.



For example, if the price for some commodity goes down, for example diesel, the costs for producing everything else will go down and it could be possible that new demand is created that didn't exist before, also more diesel being produced results, igenerally speaking, in lower production costs, so the sellers could make more money simply by selling more at a discount, even if their margins shrink a little.



At the same time, if new investiments in technology lower the price of a commodity and enables a producer to supply more markets, the competitors will die out and the leading group can set a price that takes the maximum out of the buyers' market. So a competitor will only re-enter the market if the existing market can no longer supply for every potential buyer, but then again she would have to cover all the initial costs and then the financial institution involved in this operation would be playing a major role in the business, having to consider future trends in technology etc.

It seems to me that the market mechanisms are not regulating anything, they are just reflections of production forces and fluctuations around the changing conditions of said forces.

And this perfectly highlights why a fixed currency devalues and fails over time. The goods of each market have different costs, so it is only lucrative to persue markets that cost and pay the most. I don't think this is a realistic simulation of the modern market. This simulation is assuming 1) buyers have bargaining power, 2) you are buying commodities and not needs, 3) the market isn't an oligarchy, 4) the buyers are going to many sellers instead of a few or just one, 5) it's assuming supply and demand is even being practiced, and 6) your buyers are always visiting the sellers one at a time.

1)) When you go into Krogers, you can't bargain for the price of your bananas. You have to buy at their price, or none at all.

2)) Food is something everyone needs. If you need food, you're going to buy it unless you don't actually have enough money to afford it. You can walk away from rockets.

3)) Without proper competition, competing sellers will never lower their prices. We saw that at the beginning. But how do we know how much competition do we need? Do you draw that line at 10? 20? 50?

4)) When you go to Krogers and find those bananas are more expensive than what you can get at Walmart, you might just go to Walmart for your bananas. But maybe you don't like Walmart? Maybe the difference in the cost of bananas doesn't make up for the gasoline you spent getting there? Or you're just biting the bullet and buying Bananas at Kroger because you simply don't want to take an extra 20 minutes to buy bananas at Walmart?

5)) Supply and demand also assumes that if there is a large stock, the price will go down. And in turn, if something is low in stock, the price will go up. But not all products follow this pattern, especially if the seller is knows they can get away with it. For example, printer ink cartridges cost between $0.03 - $0.08 to make, but they're still sold at $50.00 a pack.

6) capitalism has a natural tendency to monopolize. As soon as one seller gets an real edge, he gets all the customers. Lets assume he can mass produce rockets for $1 and sell it at a cutthroat price. Why would you pay $40 for a rocket when you can pay just $10. All of the other sellers lose out on their businesses. Then before you know it, there is only one seller.

i'd really like to have richard wolff's take on this. it's interesting to see what a very simplistic computer model can produce, but due to the lack of pretty much every other factor that would play into the simulation in reality, this doesn't tell us anything about real economics, which take place in a vastly more complex reality.
one simple way to make this simulation a bit more interesting would be to have the rocket sellers employ the rocket buyers. the rocket sellers have a surplus, because they sell their rockets for more than manufacturing costs. when the rocket sellers at large make a surplus, that means a relative deficit for the buyers, at least when there is no influx of money that is in some way distributed as a counter weight.
the rocket sellers can also use their surplus to invest in technology that makes manufacturing more efficient. let's say that a rocket seller acquires a rocket painting machine that is solar powered and spills less paint than a rocket seller's employee, thus is more efficient and saves the rocket seller money compared to continuing to employ a rocker buyer. the rocker buyer loses his job and has to find a source of income. unfortunately for him, all the other jobs in rocket manufacturing are taken by other rocket buyers. our jobless rocket buyer now has to offer a rocket seller to work for a lower wage than the rocket buyer does that he currently employs for him to get a job. now the rocket buyers compete for jobs that become scarcer and scarcer due to increasing automation, which leads to a further decline of wages. some now jobless rocket buyers can afford to be trained as rocket painting machine engineers that can repair said machines, but to a much lower extent than rocket buyers have lost their jobs.
in consequence some rocket buyers would need to work for such low wages that they can't afford enough food to survive. the first rocket buyers start to die due to starvation and illness.
of course there are some particularly humane rocket sellers that feel generous and share some of their wealth with the starving rocket buyers and donate to charity, as they sense that the outbreak of famine is spreading unrest in the mass of rocket buyers. some of the rocket buyers now turn violent against the rocket sellers out of desperation, others go on strike and demand higher wages.

As is often the case in science, this model does a good job illustrating concepts, but it oversimplifies a lot of things and because of that it is a pretty poor representation of real life.

It doesn't distinguish between ability to pay and willingness to pay. I mean, in real life, having access to healthcare might be a matter of life or death, meaning that one should (if they are rational) have infinite willingness to pay, but they their ability to pay might not be infinite.

It also confuses surplus with utility. 1000$ means practically nothing for a billionaire (it has very little utility) but for someone who has very little money it might mean a lot. This means that a transaction that maximize surplus doesn't necessarily maximizes utility if that surplus mostly goes to the actor which less benefits from it.

It assumes a transaction only affects participants and their competitors, which isn't necessarily the case. For example, in real life economic activities might have an environmental impact which wouldn't be represented in this model.

And it assumes that economic actors act rationally, which we know is often not the case. People can be really bad at choosing according to what's good for them. I mean, just look at gamblers.

It would be cool to see a more sophisticated realization of this concept, like an island or global economy. It's somewhat complicated but not as much as you might think... here's how I would set it up based on the three means of production and the three economic actors:

The "means of production" you always hear about can be boiled down to three categories: Land, labor and capital.

Land:
Land and natural resources. All value that exists before human (in this case blob) influence. So you drop blobs onto an island or globe, a mass populated by nodes that represent natural resources.

Labor:
Human powers that we exert on resources to improve their value. The value we create is wealth, and economically wealth is used to acquire subsistence (what we need to live), commodity (what we want because reasons) or to invest back into labor to increase its power. The blobs would have the ability to use 'energy' to turn 'resources' into 'wealth' which they have. And wealth could be saved, turned into more energy, 'fun' which makes them happy, another blob, or 'tools' that let them use less energy to make wealth.

Capital:
Capital is wealth devoted to getting more wealth rather than subsistence or commodity. You could say tools and equipment are capital, because they exist to increase the productive power of labor. But in the modern economy capital usually refers to wealth in the process of being exchanged for increase. So an active money loan or stock in a company is capital. Blobs should be able to give wealth to each other provided they will get more wealth back later from that blob at an interest rate. If it isn't repaid the blob that took the loan loses all their wealth and dies.

As there are three means of production, there are also three actors in an economy: landlords, laborers, and capitalists. These are not mutually exclusive and a person may be one, two, or all three. A blob's hue could depend on which one they are more.

Landlord: green
A landlord is someone who receives their wealth from demanding payment for the use of land and resources that weren't created by anyone. Blobs that are landlords could simply be the ones who got to a particular piece of land first, all other blobs that want to use land owned by another blob must give them a portion of their wealth produced from resources on it. The higher percentage of a blob's wealth is 'rent' made this way, the greener they are.

Laborer: red
A laborer's wealth comes from expending energy on resources to increase its value. This is the vast majority of actors in an economy. The more a blob earns from turning resources into wealth, the redder they are.

Capitalist: blue
One whose wealth is derived from returns for the supplying of capital. This person has wealth somehow. Maybe they earned it, maybe they inherited it, maybe they stole it. But they have it and they have the ability to leverage it for interest. A blob that gets more wealth as interest from capital loans becomes more blue.

Other things to consider:
The law of economics that gravity is to physics; People seek to satisfy their desires through the least exertion. The blobs want to survive, be happy, multiply, and use less energy - in that order.

On top of that, it would be cool to make the resources replenish at a rate that at first is sustainable but as the blobs expand, they threaten their resources. But maybe if they exert themselves more they can ensure they have enough to sustain their population. Would they learn to curb their consumption to keep existing or consume exponentially until they die?

There is another argument for regulation, that I'm not quite sure fits into any of the categories that you mentioned- byproducts/side-effects. A company making t-shirts might be just as happy with the price that they got from me as I am, but that doesn't mean that the people living near the t-shirt factory are happy with the company dumping chemicals in the local river. So even though regulation wasn't needed to protect/help either the buyer or the seller, it was necessary to help those who had no part in the transaction, but were effected by the making of the goods being sold.
Also, although it is very similar to the bargaining for goods, one reason to regulate has to do with labor; if there aren't enough buyers for marshmallow cakes, then no body buys them, and the company making them just goes bankrupt or folds; if there aren't enough buyers for your labor, you can't just survive and not work, so you will be forced to accept whatever terrible pay, conditions, etc. that the only buyer offers. That is why we used to have kids working 18 hour days 7 days a week, and when they lost a finger to the machinery, they were just fired, and the company didn't even stop the machines to fish the finger out of the food processors. Before regulations, when the job market got tight, people were forced to accept terrible conditions, and the buyers of labor could game the system to create a situation where the job market remained tight. Basically, companies "dying" (because there aren't enough buyers for the product/service) isn't considered a big deal, and is expected as a function of the economic system; people dying (because there aren't enough buyers of labor), however, is much more serious, and is therefore understandably treated differently. So the t-shirt company will die rather than go below its minimum acceptable price, but if no one buys my labor, I will probably not just let myself die- I will continuously lower my minimum acceptable price (and tolerated working conditions).
Don't get me wrong, I am not in favor of all regulations, and there are some that I think are ridiculous, but for the most part, regulations came about because things were going terribly wrong before they were put in place. People worked ridiculous amounts of hours before the 40 hour work week, they frequently got hurt on the job before safety regulations, when they got hurt they were just fired before stuff like worker's compensation, and consumers would get products containing gross/dangerous ingredients or non-working products before consumer protections.
We have yet to find a motivation for an economic system that works better than greed (I want the most I can get while giving up the least amount possible in return, and you want the same thing for yourself); it is reliable and has functioned for all of recorded history. However, throughout history, there are examples of the excesses of greed becoming detrimental to the system as well. Greed works well when it is kept in check, but its excesses can cause the system it supports to destroy itself. It is great for me if I can get a cheap t-shirt, but terrible for the people whose business relied on the river that the t-shirt manufacturer dumps chemicals into; greed motivated the t-shirt company to create a great shirt and deliver it to me at a fair price, but greed also caused them to dump chemicals, because doing so is cheaper than disposing of them safely, and will also cause them not to change that practice unless it starts to negatively impact their income. That is where regulation seems necessary to me- greed is the best thing to base our system on, but it has blind-spots and causes problems, which requires an outside force to counteract. In other words, greed does a lot of things well for our economic system, but it doesn't do everything well, and in those cases, we need regulations to fix the problems that greed can cause.

I defend that the market is the best on it's way and the government can't make it better, here are my objections:
When you say that a government can make changes so every there is a seller to every buyer, you don't account that maybe there is no way to sell in the price that the poorest people can buy without losing money.
Let's say there are two sellers that produce rockets, and one of them lives very far from the place that sells the rocket's parts, while the other lives nearby. The one that lives far obviously will have to charge more because he spends more time and actual money on fuel. If you simply put a law that makes the seller sell for the same price as the other, he may lose money and the transaction will not be profitable for him, so he won't do it, so then again, you will have the same problem as before, in which the buyer with less money to spend doesn't have a seller to buy from, with the addition that if you didn't had put the law, the seller would continue to sell to the other that can buy, but with the law he will probably make the investment, get caught up by the law and lose money.
Another thing is that when you change the price of products unnaturally, to attend feelings among other people instead of the supply and demand, you will create misinformation in the market, which will create miscalculated investments, which will create loss of money, which will create more poverty and create more people that can't buy things.
So there you go, the market rules.

Markets are a basic part of human existence, and emerge when enough people get together, like language and culture. However, markets are more often than not coupled with entire economic systems relating to production, distribution, and labor. An "ideal market", the libertarian and FiScaL cOnSeRvAtIvE's wet dream, doesn't exist, it's just a model devoid of real-world existence. We only ever have imperfect markets nested in larger economic systems. At that point, the question isn't "what good do markets do?" but "what good does this economic system do?"

This is why we need to recognize the use of Socialism/Communism/command economies for certain parts of our society.  Is it better to have food be in the free marketplace? Or have a single-payer system that guarantees everyone has food regardless of their ability to pay for it?  Does eliminating the need to pay for food liberate blobs to pursue more meaningful life choices?

The model used in the video was just an example used to demonstrate a simple concept. It's incredibly simplified and avoids multiple variables that would definitely complicate what is a simple 101.

With things such as food, at least in the U.S., the supply of food is far greater than the demand for food. This means prices tend to be quite low and most people can afford food. That said, it's worth noting that "food" is a fairly broad term. There are different types of food and different demand for each type. It shouldn't be difficult to understand why lobster costs way more than corn.

Another thing to note is innovation. What we didn't see in this video is how the market evolves over time. When you have people who aren't willing to pay much for existing products, there's incentive to find a way to sell to those who won't pay as much. Technology is a wonderful example of this. Not everyone is willing to pay for an iPad, but cheaper alternatives on the market exist. These alternatives aren't as good as the iPad, but they are good enough to those who don't want to spend much money on a tablet.

For example, at about 9:22-9:33 you see a bunch of sellers and buyers removing themselves from the rocket market. However, what if another seller with a relatively cheap product is introduced? As long as they remain somewhere on the left side of the graph, they can profit. When this seller is introduced, they will push all the blue bars to the right of them one space to the right. This means the product will become available to more buyers! It's not explained in this video, but there is incentive to try to nudge your way into the market - which increases the number of sales.

All of that said, swapping the graph around is far easier said than done - FAR easier said than done. The chart at 11:20 simply is not feasible. After all, people willing to pay more will always pay less if possible - which inherently means that (by pure willpower), those willing to pay more can simply stop being willing to pay more, and thus fall into a lower paying bracket. After all, these graphs only represent what people are willing to pay, not what they can pay. So, let's change what the chart represents - let's change it so that these lines now represent what people can pay. Now, people are going to be forced to pay more if they make more money, they can't simply buy cheaper products. We would need to do the same with sellers as well, so that those who make cheap products would be forced to sell to those who are willing to pay less. As far as I know, this is completely unfeasible!

What does come to mind is national health care, and I'm sure some people will use NHC as evidence of the reverse graph coming to fruition. However, NHC does not work like that. The graph represents different sellers selling different priced goods, and it shows what people are willing to pay. NHC, on the other hand, is (often) a single seller that charges people based on their income. This means we would need to use an income based chart and the average price each bracket would be FORCED to pay and the cost of goods sellers would be FORCED to sell at. These artificial systems are NOT self-sustaining, thus they are prone to problems that aren't present in the free market or, at the very least, are resolves MUCH differently. The minimum selling price that the blue blobs would be willing to sell to the orange blobs is based on the capacity of units (rockets) they can make (or are willing to make without sacrificing the contribution margin of the next rocket sold). Assuming each blue blob is making the amount of units needed to satisfy demand for the rockets without going over the capacity of rockets it can make, it would (from an accounting stand point) sell its rockets for a minimum selling price of Sell$= variable costs of each rocket less any discounts they get from satisfying that specific trade of units. Variable costs of a rocket would be something like cost of material for that rocket, labor wage paid for that rocket, overhead (extra) manufacturing costs for that rocket. Hope that gives more context to the idea of where the minimum selling price is ideally derived from for the perspective of the blue blob selling the rockets!

An interesting followup to this would be how the profit/loss system contributes to automatically organizing the market, e.g. sellers making large profits rewards the business with capital to grow while also encouraging more sellers to invest in and enter the market, while sellers making losses punishes them by shrinking them and drives them and other businesses. Similarly, how sellers across the entire economy implicitly compete with each other over the price of inputs (labor, raw materials) and how such prices organize economic activity. For instance, since revenue is roughly analogous to "value buyers place on the product" and expenses is roughly analogous to "cost of the inputs", a "profit" means "the output is more valuable than the input" i.e. economic value was created, whereas a "loss" means "the output is less valuable than the input" i.e. economic value was destroyed - thus, a profit-maximizing economy is by definition a value-maximizing economy. Similarly, an increase in price for a specific input (representing greater scarcity or increased demand) makes the least profitable activities with said inputs become outright unprofitable, driving out both the least efficient sellers as well as the least valuable uses for that input (since profit is "value created in excess of input").

I think an interesting addition to this would be seller and buyer growth with a limited collective cash pool. The sellers are totally limited in their income by what the buyers buy. Each purchase results in the seller getting that much pocket money and if they have enough pocket money they can put out more rockets to sell. This would simulate the growth of the seller, likely resulting in effectively a couple "supermarket" sellers. Then the buyers must lose however much of their money they spent on buying rockets. For the fun of it, we'll also assume the blobs are all rocket scientists and need these rockets for their job. Each day, they use up however many rockets they bought up and gain some specified amount of money per rocket they have. It's pretty obvious what would happen here since the richest buyers and the lowest sellers eventually have a positive feedback loop where they will simply continue to gain infinitely more money, while the poorest buyers and the highest sellers will likely "die off" without being able to buy or sell anything. However, I think it could be an interesting starting point with economic theory regarding income.

I think a few more important factors to also add in are:
1. A transaction may be good for the two individuals involved but may cause harm to others. Which may not be great for society as a whole. For instance if your transaction involved polluting the environment.
2. There can be an incentive to "create demand" in the market. i.e. you might sell an addictive product or try to convince society that they are ugly and therefore need to buy your beauty products. Although you are filling the immediate need with your transactions you've harmed society overall by creating the demand in the first place.

Another characteristic of the model is missing from a lot of real markets: each transaction has no effect on anyone except that the buyer loses money and gains a rocket while the seller loses a rocket and gains money.  If some other blob breathes a bunch of smoke every time a rocket is sold, the results won't be optimal: things could be better if the price paid by the buyer were higher to account for the smoke damage so that the only transactions done are those where the benefit exceeds the whole cost.  (Or if the price received by the seller were lower.  As long as the external cost gets paid.)  And if some other blob gets to watch pretty fireworks whenever a rocket is sold, the results won't be optimal either: things could be better if there were if the price received by the seller were higher.  (Or if the price paid by the seller were lower.  As long as the external benefit is paid for.)

This video is an EXCELLENT example of how mathematical models can deviate from real world behavior/results, simply due to lack of data / "assumed" data. In your theoretical market, like you said, it's "efficient" and works near automatically. However when you try to account for variables that aren't always constant (lack of monopolies, everyone having access to transaction, etc), and account for "marketizing" other aspects of life--i.e. NEEDS--you realize that a system built on autopilot doesn't always output what people could consider "the desired outcome." In other words, what's "good for the system" isn't always "good for everyone."

It's entertaining but the downsides of all these simulations are that the assumptions made are political at their very core.
Some commenters ask for simulations of the societal scale or comparing capitalism and socialism. But such simulations cannot be done w/o setting up premises on things like "human nature" which there is no consensus on, nor the evolution of it.

There are markets where it become cheaper to provide the service/product the more consumption there are. For instance, high tech electronics where most of the cost comes from research and development rather than production. The cost of research and development of a phone stays the same if you sell 100 as if you sell 1000 so the RnD cost per product will got down the more phones you sell while the production cost per phone is relatively constant. This could perhaps be simulated by letting the lowest price a seller is willing to sell at go down every time they sell a product.

There are also other effects such as a product might be more valuable for a consumer the more people that are buying it. For instance, if only one person has a phone it is pretty useless while if all of that persons friends has a phone it is a very useful communication device and that person would value it more. This could be simulated by having a different maximum price for every seller that a buyer is willing to pay and every time a product of, let say seller x, is sold every buyers maximum price for seller x goes up.

The problem with this is that in the real world, these markets don't exist in a vacuum where rockets are magically created at the beginning of each day and everyone's bottom price stays the same. If a seller makes enough money, they can start to do things like buying their stock in bulk, or contracts for repeated sales, etc which reduces their minimum price because each rocket costs less for them to acquire. Once this occurs, they naturally get more business, as their minimum price becomes lower than most other sellers on the market. When that happens, the expected value of the buyers goes down, until eventually the expected price for most buyers becomes lower than the minimum for other sellers and those sellers go out of business. Once this happens it becomes incredibly hard for any new sellers to enter the market because they can't afford to do those things that the bigger sellers can in order to reduce their minimum price, meaning that what you're left with is a few massive sellers that entered the market super early squeezing out all competition, not because they're evil or actively trying to stifle competition, but simply because they're working in their own best interest.
This is how we end up with massive corporations run by billionaires that hold the vast majority of the market share and own more wealth than the bottom 90% of the USA combined.


tl;dr Bigger businesses inherently kill off small businesses because they can afford to sell for less than small businesses

Just like in 5:55 one of the sellers can't keep up, and so does not sell, the same can happen in similar situation where buyers can't keep up, and so can't keep buying. If instead of rockets they where buying water, food, healthcare, or housing, then the potential buyer that "can't keep up" just dies. This is a brutal system. In the demand and supply graph those buyers (demand curve) that have a negative surplus (to the right of the equilibrium in your graph) die.

Buyers normally don't limit their individual demand to one unit of a certain product. Rich buyers can buy many rockets and so they affect the equilibrium price as if they where many people that demanded one rocket. Free Market is often portrayed like a continuos 'referendum' where people decide what the adequate price of something should be, but in this 'referendum' not everyone has the same purchasing power and so not everyone has the same 'vote'. This is a plutocracy. Stop and think about the moral consequence of this fact in an economy where the top 1% owns more wealth than the bottom 50% of the population. It is often far profitable to provide WANTS for the rich (often in the form of financial assets to get richer), than it is to provide NEEDS to the poor.

Your description of the invisible hand is actually a common misconception. The "invisible hand", as coined by Adam Smith in the 18th century, actually refers to the belief that people acting in their own self-interest to maximize their own utility will in turn reap unintended social benefits for all of society. Essentially, it argues that optimal economic output corresponds with optimal social output.

I mean, this video is pretty nice but I will have to disagree a little. There are multiple reasons (purely logical and also empirical ones) that point towards free markets being the best option always. When competition in some area seems dead there is always new ways to get in the competition (think train monopolies destroyed by cars and airplanes).
Ultimately, intervening the market has the effect of distortioning prices. Which are the fundamental tool for guiding production. Where wealth is increased by the right products being made in the right ammount.
Also the reasons you suggest for it being desirable to regulate the market is something that happens in a free market. That's mistake two you make in that regard. The first one was saying that it organizes "automatically". From far away it seems that way but from upclose it's every individual interaction that organizes it. So it's not a mindless autmatic organization, it's the result of every comercial interaction made conciously by each individual. And from upclose it seems as you are only counting on the surplus of each individual for organizing it but, in the big scale, every price is determined by the combination of surplus of every buyer and seller.
Lastly I recommend "The Road to Serfdom" to understand that regulating "markets" according some "greater good" ideal end up in full regulation and tyranny by goverment. That's not to say that the goverment doesn't have an important role in society, or even in the market. It can participate and produce things for people that couldn't afford it otherwise but it will only work as long as it trades in a free market that has real prices and a healthy economy that produces so much it can sustain said goverment.
I also recomend "Human action" for a more in-depth understanding.

I don't like either the "invisible hand" or "everything happens automatically".
I prefer "without top-down design" or "organized by people voluntarily".
All of this organization very often is the result of human design, like E-bay designing a reputation system.

You didn't provide any evidence for why government meddling is ever beneficial.
What makes sense to you isn't good enough to argue for government policy.

Even if you have a strong ideology that favors money being spend on particular product or service, there's no evidence this ever benefited society.
It sure has benefited some individuals, but these arguments are about society as a whole.
In fact the evidence we have points in the other direction, in general economic freedom correlates with higher quality of life:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/shanedk/sets/72157646459874723/

The causal relationship is that violating the Non-Agression Principle causes misery:

I love that you provided four specific points where government might benefit society, lets discuss them.

1. Many buyers and sellers
Proven false by the computer industry.
It often only has a few businesses for a product or service and often the leader has 90%+ of the market.
Yet in the computer industry quality consistently goes up with price consistently going down.
Potential competition is enough to achieve this effect.
Which is why standard oil kept oil prices low, when government started meddling, they'd already been losing market share.

And without government it's far too expensive and not profitable at all to keep competition out.
Only by making the public pay for creating barriers to entry, can such policies be profitable.

2. Freedom to transact with anyone
Again; the only one who can afford to enforce this is government, because they can steal the money to pay for it.
Even if there's a natural resource that only one person/company has access to, there's always alternatives.
So instead of oil, use nuclear energy, by raising prices to greatly motivate the development of those alternatives.

3. Voluntary participation
Government is the only one who can force you to buy their product or sell your property.
In the previous century alone governments murdered over 200 million people for not disobeying the totalitarian state, as compared to an estimated 9 million murders that where committed privately.
Surely, in most western societies few people are murdered by the state for disobedience, but state action still always causes more misery than benefit.

4. Good information
There's a cost to having/providing information and it's quality.
Who determines how much information is needed or how much should be spend on improving it's quality?
Everyone is different and in practice one size fits almost nobody.
So whatever level of information government chooses to require will be the wrong level for almost everyone.
Should the information include the diet of factory workers?
Please don't try to repeat the disaster of centralized control.

Conclusion:
The problems caused by monopolies/cartels are actually caused by governments raising barriers to entry.
Here's a few examples of policies that do this:
- Licensing (literally a monopoly)
- Patents
- Tariffs
- Regulation (with the Clean Air Act existing polluters where specifically allowed to keep polluting)

That is determined by customers.
By choosing where to and not to spend their money.

Among the assumptions at 10:43 the one about informed participants in the market is actually definitively false in the real world. A lot of sells happen due to ignorance of the general consensus on pricing.
Another one that is false is the freedom to transact. Because one thing you didn't take into account in your model is that there is a cost of going to one stall to another in reality. And a cost to bring your rocket back home. But that means that distributing different buyers and sellers differently will lead to different price despite expectation not changing.


The argument about "voluntary participation" is also one that is definitely not fullfilled for market like healthcare, food, shelter and labor, because everyone has to participate in those, which is why it's definitely a good idea to make sure everyone can get access to it, you can't just walk away and say "yeah I'll pass on food". And the thing is that your model doesn't take into account that the maximum price a buyer will offer isn't always associated with it's need in those kind of markets, but also with it's available money, which needs it might be willing to pay more if it could, but might not be able to.


Also you assume your buyers don't communicate with each other and don't try to agree on a price less favorable for the customer but more favorable to all of them.


Well those aren't the only things obviously (you could think about the impact of sellers also being buyers for exemple), and I get that they are beyond the scope of the video, but I also wanted to point out how many unfounded assumption this model has, because a lot of political views about economy talk about how amazing markets are abstractly without actually looking at how human market work for real.

The initial bit could probably get a video on its own, because it gets into the nature of economic value. Value is weird because it's ultimately subjective. There's probably an argument to be made that at the end of the day it all boils down to utility, which makes sense in a way, but even then it remains subjective. Supply and demand, after all. Water will be worth more in a desert than in New York. Likewise, while sand isn't particularly expensive, it is sold for certain things. Good luck selling sand to someone in a desert.

The interesting thing is that this even applies to money. The value of money comes (in the immediate, day-to-day sense) from the fact that you can buy stuff with it. That makes it REALLY useful. Despite that, the money can't do much itself. What winds up happing is that a sale happens when the seller values the money he's selling for more than that he's offering, and when the buyer values what he's buying more than the money he's spending. That's the surplus.

The interesting thing here is that this results in both people having MORE VALUE, by their estimation, than they started with. Value is ultimately not zero-sum (which is to say that there isn't a finite amount of value that can only be moved around). Value can be created simply through trade.

The beauty of the free market isn’t simply that it allows for maximization or surplus and decreased price, but the ability for participants to innovate and improve upon older products.

Think of it like an iPhone. The current iPhone model is usually around $1,000.00 while a model from between 2-5 years ago ranges from $100.00-$300.00. This way, buyers unwilling or unable to buy the more expensive product can more easily afford an older one, and in a few years, should they wish, could afford that newer model they couldn’t before.

As for sellers, those who can’t compete have three choices: innovate, reprioritize, or shut down. Most companies that can’t innovate, either through technological or financial limitations, usually reprioritize themselves in order to stay afloat. A great example is Motorola and Nokia. Both used to produce top-of-the-line cellphones, but were beaten out by Apple and Samsung. They eventually restructured themselves and are still around, in one form or another, to this day.

The force part is the most relevant in my opinion. People in many countries are forced to buy things- for instance, in a country swept by a plague, everyone would need to buy medical treatment. The "need" immediately collapses a free market. The same applies to food and shelter- some kind always has to be present. It's okay if more money gets you better versions of that, but people die if they don't have that. Yes, die. All those communism/fascism jokes about "Finally some ____ [omitted] food" do have a basis, because totalitarian governments tend to pander to charging more for basic needs due to bribery. That's why those things need to be regulated properly. The rest of the free market works just fine. When a liberal man tells a conservative one that there needs to be more regulation, he means the "need" factor. And when a conservative man tells a liberal man that there needs to be less, he means that without the "need" factor. The majority of financial politics is just people arguing over the principle as opposed to the specifics. I'm not going to talk about the other side- taxation- because that will start a huge brawl, but the capitalism debate has a very clear answer.

Would be interesting if you could expand on this video by introducing the concept of externalities ie as often happens in real world situations where some portion of the surplus or some portion of the costs accrues to a party not involved in the transaction. As a couple of simple examples consider a healthcare market but instead of only having buyer and seller (B and S) you also have employer E that gains some surplus if B is able to make a transaction and thus calls in sick less often. Or a market in which farmer F sustains a cost due to S contaminating the water source of their farm etc. Those are a couple of classic examples that lead to attempts at corrective market actions through regulation in order to make the market more efficient by ensuring everything is fully costed in the price to avoid failings that result in tragedy of the commons type market failures etc.

this is a very good introduction to supply and demand. however that last remark is a can of worms, market monopolies are extremely bad for economic equilibrium, artificial manipulation is also bad for economic equilibrium, and the worst thing for an economy are special interest entitlements.


market manipulation is not good but may be better than a predatory market, it is best used as a temporary fix. predatory markets include monopolies, oligopolies(monopoly of the few), Corporatism (government enforced sellers and producers), and extreme competition markets.


monopolies are bad because like with your first few examples with supply and demand the price will rise indefinitely in spite of more economically efficient methods being available, who owns the monopoly is not of consequence this is simply what they do.


Oligopolies are like monopolies but multiple producers are either coordinating or are deadlocked in a extremely competitive market with an isolated monopoly control like geographic, demographic, or legal/technological.


Corpratism is when one company doesn't have a monopoly but dictates the market either through government regulation or by exception from government regulation. this is often called regulatory capture.


Extreme competition markets are markets with a high cost of entry and a low profit margin, this may be caused by the above, but more commonly is the result of new market creation. an example of which is the DOT COM boom and bust as well as the many tech boom and busts. the most current examples are in fringe space technology, and information communication infrastructure and technology (4G/5G). sometimes this will occur purely due to a sudden increase of producers or sudden increase of consumers, an example of which is construction.

Another thing about markets is that they are easily manipulated by capital. Capital operates on the long term and naturally coordinates with its competition. Consumers operate on immediate satisfaction and do not organize whatsoever. Therefore, Capital will always maneuver to the point where surplus is MAXIMIZED for them, while consumers will trade freely until their surplus is completely eliminated. Markets therefore naturally tend to this state, which is a monopoly with discriminatory pricing.

According to supply and demand theory, all profits should run to zero in a competitive market, but there is a reason that does not happen anymore. Capital understands that competitive markets are not advantageous to them, so they simply do not allow competitive markets to exist.

In other words, the problem with supply and demand is that it assumes that all blobs are stupid and myopic, but in reality, some humans are very saavy and driven to dominate others by any means necessary.

This simulation is totally inacurate, because it simulates the auction-style market where supply is limited.
in the real market, supply is always infinite as long as you are willing to pay the price.
in the real market, any of those blue blobs can saturate the market all by itself and drive other sellers out of the market.
at the same time, buyers have limited capacity in terms of ability to consume and ability to pay.


In that situation, the market will always end with a monopoly where every niche of the market will be dominated by a certain seller and the rice will depend on the market entry costs since monopolist has to keep the price as high as possible but at the same time low enough to make any kind of competition unfeasible.
Also, there is another equilibrium where you can get the highest profits from the economy of scale as you can sell 1 item that costs 10 for 100 and get a profit of 90 or you can sell 1000 items for 11 and get a profit of 1000. or even 6000 because cost of making one item is 10 while the cost of making 1000 items is 5

The thing with the healthcare and food example, is that it underestimates both the efficiency of the sellers, and the demand of the buyers. On one hand, a handful of sellers can produce enough for the demand of all buyers, and yet all buyers could still be sated by buying from the most efficient ones, pushing other sellers out of the market; and because having food is necessary for survival, their demand is effectively infinite until they have sated their needs to sustain themselves. One effect of this, is that if they have a limited income, then the higher the price of food, the lower the price they will accept for any other product, and the lower the price of food, the higher the price they'll pay for anything else. They will not make any decisions about the price of anything else, until their most urgent needs have been met.
Now, you may assume this would suggest that the sellers would infinitely push the prices up until everyone is spending the entirety of their budget on food... But there's another factor; there are alternatives to buying food from others; and that's to make or gather it yourself. For example, if the price of meat is higher than the price of going out and hunting a deer, people will go out and hunt deer; and if its cheaper to rear animals for food than either of those two options, people will go into animal rearing. These people, once would be buyers, if they ever produce more than they need, thus become sellers.
Thus, in a food market, the buyers on the right side of the graph could be interpreted as being, perhaps, the same people as the sellers... In fact, that's another thing the simulation is missing; every buyer can become a seller if offered the right price. In fact, the thresholds for both buying and selling, are likely one in the same, but from different sides. At any price above the threshold, they'll sell, at any price bellow, they'll buy.

It's interesting that this was never modeled with more than one good in question. It was argued that surplus is maximized in the case of one good, but real people have fixed total budgets, with flexible pricepoints for individual goods as long as that total budget is not exceeded.
