First of all there's no need for a market to have "many" buyers and sellers because defining what would constitute as "many" is either tricky if not outright impossible since there is no single number that can actually represent "many", since it is a relativistic and subjective measurment, also there's no such thing as "good information" for the same reasons i said earlier, every agent has their own idea of what constitutes "good information". Not only that, you already said that the model itself works to have the right amount of participants, so we only stay with 2 + 1 requirements: voluntary participation, freedom of entry and exit for goods, services and people (wich is the defining aspect of competion) and an extra wich would be the price system to be left alone as much as possible. The reason why people can't afford things like food, job or healthcare in a developed country is precisely because of the economic policies and regulations tends to increase prices and taxation and inflation reduces the purchasing power of the consumer, specially on the lower income brackets. For example in the case of heakthcare in the united states you have insurance companies that monopolycing the health insurace in a certain state(wich means the goverment actively reduces competion), with no competition you have practices like price gouging, in adition the regulations forcing hospitals to follow certain procedures make the service more expensive. In the labor market regulations like minimun wages drive up the price of labor artificially, if the price of labor rises the market will react with less employment(as you exposed in the video), then the rise in unemplyment will drive the workers to work for less money or worse conditions, after all all those goverment funded retirement plans, taxes, health insurance and other beneffits are also a kind of profit or surplus wich are paid in kind instead of money.

I love your work and everything you do to simulate it. I know it requires a lot of hard work with fixed variables and at the same time, fixed variables are the problem for this particular Supply and Demand video. Why? Well, to start off, it is set up backwards. Usually if you're the only seller, you set outrageous prices after you realize what people are willing to buy  because no one else can contend (historical event on monopoly citation here).  Your fixed variables are imprecise because they're based on a "perfect" economy which is derivative on a limited yet liquidative resource per simulation which lacks its modernism of today's supply and demand. If every single one of the businesses had a larger quantity of product so they could sell more than 1 per consumer and if the consumer can buy it, then what needs to be set is how much a business can own and sell in quantity. The larger they can afford bulk, the more they can save by selling in lower prices. That is how a modern day Supply and Demand is working. Because let's be honest, the consumer will always end up paying due to it being a necessity and against the law to steal- like food. The 3rd problem is that you're listing supply and demand as something that is not heavily manufactured, because in reality it is. Everything is. Otherwise your supply and demand simulation would mean that finding the equilibrium was pointless because you're simulating it in an economy, not actually supplying a demand. As always, I look forward to your more enjoyable content.

Mistake starting at 10:24. Those are requirements (or ideal market) for the price determination model, not for actual markets. Notice, for example that the price determination model expects the entire market to move to the equilibrium price and quantity, whereas the real world has surplus being produced at quantities all the way to the very left of the graph AND at slight variations on the equilibrium price per individual transaction. The model needs such “perfect markets” to work as a model, but perfect markets do not need to exist for the concept explained by the model in order for it to apply to them. So you got everything else right, except the assumptions of the model, which are applicable only to the model and not the practical application as you explained it. Seems like nit-picking, but since that is the entire basis for arguing in favour of intervention, the impact or implication of that small mistake is huge.

The idea that the best possible way of getting the maximum quantity of “surplus”, which is really more just “purchase/sale satisfaction”, is through markets, based on this model at least, is contingent on the fact that the supply curve and demand curve are entirely independent of markets whatsoever, and will be the same (or at least act the same within the model) without markets (or when the markets are otherwise modified), which is fundamentally untrue.

The market you describe lacks 2 essential components: agency and capitalization. The "inefficnent" sellers don't just stand there, they are acquired by the "efficient" ones through resources collected and stored (aka capitalization). As such, number of sellers decreases and buyers have to start competing, increasing capitalization even more, which leads to one or very few monopolies controlling the market, being the most effective and setting cohesive prices. Then, they start to protect their interests through forging the government connections, reducing concurrency to one ore two monopolies. Feels familiar, right?

I appreciated your video as a good explanation of neoclassical economic theory to the point you said that "some real markets are pretty close to this ideal". I don't know if this statement comes from a personal bias or was just a mistake but that's far from reality: two of the main pillars of this theory, that agents are perfectly informed and rational, are impossible to achieve, unless a third party (a government or and independent agency or whatever) constantly analyses markets, informs people and/or prevents irrational choices and that would make the market not free. If those assumptions were just an approximation of reality, and not plainly wrong, any "free enough" market would heavily punish things like "incredible offers", in which a cheap product is suggested to be available at a price incredibly convenient but actually much higher of its "real" one, or companies that work more on appearance and status symbol, than to substance, to overprice their goods in comparison to competitors.


An example is youtube: if consumers were perfectly rational being they would invest far more time watching your videos, instead of wasting hours (equivalent of money in other markets, and that makes the assumption on consumer surplus wrong) enriching idiots that play videogames while screaming.

By the way, with "invisible hand" Adam Smith was referring to divine providence and the concept remains the same today. Astrologists nowadays like to justify their beliefs with a lot of math but that doesn't make their ideas more scientific, since basic assumptions remain superstitions.

This representation of markets is inaccurate, you're showing supply and demand as price desired for the products by each party, in a real world free market what you are trying to represent actually organizes itself in the way you do in the final graphic where the suppliers who desire the highest price for their product tend to sell to those willing to spend the most on the products and those who desire the lowest price tend to sell to those willing to spend the least, "government intervention" actually flips the graph to what you had in most of the video where people willing to spend the most are steered towards suppliers who desire the least for their product while people who wish to spend the least are steered towards suppliers who desire the most for their product, then the government makes up for the difference between the two on either side by adding money to the transaction, artificially inflating average prices to closer to whatever the maximum market value on either side is

That's an overly simplistic interpretation of Adam Smith's "invisible hand" theory. Since it's not only about the market's self-organizing ability but about the relationship between businesses and families where Smith predicted that businesses will always have the family's interest at heart. That is in no way true which is why economists rarely talk about the "invisible hand" anymore except when they are talking about Adam Smith specifically.

I want to address the topic of products/services that everybody needs, such as healthcare. While the buyers can rarely increase their maximum buying price to make purchases, the sellers very much can reduce their minimum selling price, whether that be by providing a lower quality service or figuring out how to be more cost efficient. I believe that what would happen is that a new market would emerge, selling a similar, but lower quality service for the people that can't afford the higher quality service. That doesn't necessarily mean that the buyers with a higher maximum buying price will make the switch to the lower quality service however, as they are willing or able to pay more for better service.


The market is an incredibly complicated with things such as selling points and cost reduction that could affect the statistics that we gather from simulations such as this one. I believe that the earlier years of the United States of America, which is one of the closest examples we have of a free market society, was able to become one of the most dominant superpowers in history that people would yearn to immigrate to, because of the limited government intervention in the market. There was a correlation between hard work and prosperity and so people were in charge of their success. I hope that one day, we can return to that America that is responsible for so much of what we enjoy today.
What may be worth noting is that as different sellers compete with each other, their minimum selling price will also lower as they seek out more cost efficient ways to produce their product.

interesting. I really enjoy this video. While in a flat market that is helpful but the economy is set up for a debtor nation. Which is a strange concept. The goal of the debtor nation is to have the interest rate be lower than the inflation. America's current set up. In fact most countries set up.

This means that if you can get an item for an interest rate lower than the actual cost the debt lowering in cost to the buyer. Why is this such an issue. The common person is not able to get a loan that is not able to get that interest rate. Only the top can. Normally governments and companies. This also has another effect. The workers who's wages don't raise with interest rates they start to earn less as time goes on.

This is a down side to a debtor nation. Why is this a bad thing will the value of the money can under go inflation at a rapid rate especially when a market is designed to increase surplus for one side. Even more so when one party is breaking the rules to play that game. (the last recession is a prime example)

Sadly the market for when the currency is increasing in value is flawed. The wages go up but the goods and services go down. which means that the sellers are taking the lose. So in practice bot are bad in a long haul. Sellers take a loss than not companies, Debtor nation leads to rapid growth in prices which left unchecked can have market crashes as well as the competition for good cause issues.

Adam Smith wrote of the Invisible Hand twice, in neither case in the context of self-balancing markets.  In The Theory of Moral Sentiments he states that the rich will be "obliged" to share "nearly the same distribution of the necessaries of life" with their servants and laborers than if "the earth been divided into equal portions".  In The Wealth of Nations he states that merchants etc will unintentionally "promote the public interest [...] By preferring the support of domestic to that of foreign industry" and "pursuing his own interests".

There is a problem, namely what you just briefly mentioned: A set of buyers and sellers are left out of the market. This propagates that items on the market need a certain worth from the buyer and seller to manufacture and obtain, locking the market to those who have amassed... exchange capacity(?) before it's introduction.
The fact that there are sellers ready to sell as low as the buyer with the least EC means that the product can be made, and the exchange can provide enough EC for the seller to continue business. If a model propagates this, then more products will be made and sold, and the only limit would be the probably rising manufacturing price, if the product is made from limited rescources. This however, is unaviodable by definition.


So, what am I saying is that getting rid of the irregularities in expected selling price helps markets and the population overall.

It's a good illustration, but a big problem I see with this model, is that it leaves out the problem of monopolies. If a blue blob happens to not strike a deal a couple times it would be removed from the market. This is not only a problem for the blue blob who now has to explain it's blob children why there won't be a any blob toys for Christmas, but also for the the orange blob as on competitor was removed from the market thus lowering the offers to choose from.
In the real world big companies with huge reserves could even undercut smaller competitors to drive them from the market even if it means they a operating at a loss, since their larger reserves allow them to keep up with this list longer. After competitors are driven from the market they can use their newly established monopoly to rise prices as the buyers are deprived from alternatives.
Preventing such monopolies from forming is also an instance where intervention in the market can be worthwhile or even necessary.

A fun video but there is an extremely important flaw at 3:57. The min sell price is $20 and the max is $40...the video determines with just one buyer and seller, they will settle on a halfway point ($30). In reality this is not true. They could easily settle on $22 or $38, or $33...there is no mathematical rule that determines this should be split evenly at exactly the halfway point. As long as the seller sells above the min price and the buyer buys below his max price, everybody is happy. This is an important flaw that undermines the subsequent and derivative tests. In realty, bargaining power determines whether a a rocket will be sold between $21 and $39 dollars. In reality, the sellers would try to get together to improve their bargaining power (merger, corporate growth, etc...), while the buyer would try to increase their bargaining power through a labor union or another company. Just like games theory, bargaining power is a game of chicken in which the larger party can bluff withdrawing from exchange to get a larger share of the increment of association. I suggest you run this simulation again...but this time factor in collective bargaining power. I think it would have shocking results.

You missed some fundamental facts and got some things wrong. You take the seller to be a just anyone who just happens to have some goods lying around. That's wrong, as the "market" in a market economy is the last phase in a production process, the circulation phase. You just ignored that its a process. For example the customers themselves arent just some random people having money lying around. They are overwhelmingly workers who get their money from working for one of the sellers (or somewhere along the line), so they add to the price, the production cost. They are cost in the production process, which is to be minimised.
Then your notion of "surplus" is wrong either, as surplus is the first condition for a business to operate. If there is none they have to close their doors, on the other hand every transaction that takes place already has its surplus calculated in. Whats youre taking about is rent, the consumer and producer rent, which are concepts that have shown to be wrong. Skipping some detail I'll just leave it like that: there is so such thing as the maximum which someone is willing to pay, which is practically devoted to some good and when you dont have to spend it all on the good you magically created some profit for yourself. That "profit" - you even call it surplus - is a fiction. When thinking about it differently some how you cant find it any more.
Real surplus is produced when someone buys goods and labour so sell it at a markup, and that repeatedly.

Mmmhhh... The problem with healthcare and food is that the demand doesn't drop when prices go up, because it is and indipendent factor.
Let's say a broken leg was "amendable" for free and the community you live in had an average of 10 broken legs a day. If you turned the price up, you'd still have 10 broken legs a day because having a broken leg is not a choice, it is dictated by circumstances; hence, supply and demand do not regulate themselves as with "regular products": you could make people pay between 16k and 35k dollars for a broken leg and that would not affect the number of legs broken. You could theoretically raise the prices forever without having a drop in the demand.
The only difference is that people who are outside of the price range don't get their legs mended, thus posing a very high risk of incapacitation for life, something that must not have a price on.

Markets are good only when they regulate non-essential goods, like books, rockets, cars, ecc. They are trash when regulating essential goods, healtcare, education, food, ec. , since the "demand-supply" mechanism won't work; in the latter case, the trade of such things must be regulated by law or something equivalent.

There is maximized net value/wealth created for the blobs when the markets are allowed to freely clear (as illustrated). This is more advantageous to the blobs since it maximizes what the society of blobs can do, even if it means some blobs can not all profit in a given market - very rare NBA blobs.

I would argue that it should be left up to the individual blobs with their maximized wealth to determine how to spend the maximized wealth. Reinvest it to democratize a technology? Save it for later? Buy food? Buy an apartment complex for homeless blobs? Build a free hospital for the blobs? Become a patron of the lousy rocket builders but phenomenal artist blobs?

Any of those wealth spending efforts can only be maximized by allowing the wealth to be maximized since they can only exist proportional to and after the surplus exists. Introducing non-market (state) controls can only diminish wealth and therefore diminish what is done with that wealth.

Great video! I'll add my two cents on what's Wrong with the market (and it's not a problem of the tool, but of the participants): the participants engage in the market based on Expected value, but not on the "real" value generated to themselves. To give an example, a person buys a dress expecting to be happy. However, the moment she brings it home, she leaves it in the closet for several months, then realizes that it doesn't even fit her. The value of that dress to her is now negative, especially when you consider that she has a whole bunch of them clogging up her closet.


Unfortunately, the average participant is Pretty bad at adjusting their spending behavior based on feedback from the actual outcome of their last purchase, so instead of questioning the behavior, they repeat it for something bigger ("I didn't get much satisfaction from my new car, therefore I need a new more expensive one.") However, the way our brain is wired, any state becomes "normal" after a while, which is why people are always fighting to climb the economic ladder, but are never satisfied.

Great videos. However, the idea and reasoning that markets are bad or need help could be improved. At 10:39 you listed four requirements for ideal markets. However, those four requirements are off shoots of only one requirement. If the individuals have freedom (liberty), then you will have ideal markets. For instance, the requirement for many buyers and sellers - if individuals are free to become a buyer, or seller, then you will have the ideal number of buyers and sellers. If you have individual liberty, then you have the freedom to transact with anyone. Liberty allows for voluntary participation. And, liberty allows individuals to only decide (to buy or sell) if and when they have enough information to do so, in their own opinion of if they have enough information.

What does not work is when others limit liberty of individuals to be buyers or sellers. We see government limiting both supply and demand in many if not most markets. We see government limiting who can transact with whom, via regulations, licenses, labor restrictions, union requirements and the like. We see government forcing or restricting participation in markers (Obamacare an obvious example). And government makes rules about what information must or must not be shared on products and services.

Taking the first requirement as an example - in a free market, if one determines that there are not enough suppliers in a sub-market, and that prices are too high of course, then one can become a supplier in said market. This is the free market solution, which is far superior and consistent with your video, than government regulations, price controls and the typical regulations that end up destroying the market in the first place.

Hi, nice video animation.
But there are some things that are very weird (but i am no expert in economics):
1) I don't see why one should say that the buyer gets "surplus" if the price he buys the rocket is below the price he expected. I feel that the term should be used only for the seller if he gets above the price he got the rocket. For this particular example, the seller was willing to use some of his money to become a seller, buying the rockets and opening a shop. Once he do that he needs to sell otherwise he is loosing money, because he has no reason to keep the rockets if some buyer shows up, other than waiting for some other buyer to offer a better deal. The buyer on the other hand will buy if he thinks that the price is not outrageous and he has enough money to buy the rocket, of course he will search for the lower price but saying he got surplus is like he is 10 dollars richer after the transaction. It is as if the buyer already had spent 40 dollars just form the intention of buying a rocket and by getting the deal for 30, magically, he was given a 10 dollar bill.

2)It is very strange to say that the market organized it self. You organized it that way, you wrote an algorithm that did just that and then got surprised of the thing doing some kind of unexpected thing : organizing that way. You wrote the rules, i repeat you organised it, then by mathematically analysing your algorithm, found out its behaviour. But it didn't self organize, you had to carefully write the behaviour of each of the "agents". Maybe something we could say instead is that we suppose that people willing to trade, will more or less organize this way.

3) this thing of generating maximum surplus at the equilibrium is also very strange. Maybe you should have given the proof because i don't see why it is true. You just said that the next buyer and seller will make negative surplus, meaning that the couple buyer and seller that meet at the equilibrium are actually making zero profit. When prices stabilize at the equilibrium actually profits end, your algorithm is just making each agent tend towards this couple where the curves meet.

You could simulate a situation where the blobs are subject to natural selection in a monopolistic healthcare market. They collect money based on certain money-collecting traits, like intelligence, social connections, or wealth of a blobs parents, and stumbling-block traits that make blobs miss out on money like being born with a disability or sustaining an injury. These traits could be treated with healthcare. If they don't get enough money, they cant buy healthcare and die if they were born with or develop a condition, or die if they don't have enough money for food. You could just subtract a set amount of money from a blob's savings to simulate a blob buying and eating food. You could set the price of healthcare with a monopolistic model based on the willingness to pay of the blobs, which would be dependent on the income distribution of the blobs. I think that as income distribution increases, healthcare would increase, causing blobs with traits that are not competitive in capitalism to die. In other words, as the rich get richer, undesirables die.

This goes into price discrimination. Basically, a buyer is able to know the maximum price any costumer is willing to pay for a good and will only charge that price, so the producer surplus is maximized and the consumer surplus is zero. This is (basically) the pricing model behind bidding on eBay and when you haggle for a price on a car.

But say the monopolist is not able to differentiate between individual costumers so the demand for each costumer is unknown. Now the monopolist only knows the aggregate demand (AD) of all the costumers through marketing data, so the demand curve can be drawn. Say the monopolist can only charge one price for their good or service. What price do they charge? A suuuper high price, but not too high. This price can be calculated from the quantity where the monopolists change in production cost (MC) is equal to the change in revenue (MR), and that quantity's corresponding price on the demand curve. For example, say MR = MC = $1, and at $1, quantity = 10. If Q = 10, then say on the demand curve customers are willing to pay $10 when Q = 10. This is a massive price increase compared to what it costs the monopolist to produce at. This is why you may see not all but many life saving pharmaceuticals being produced inexpensively, yet sold at a very high price. This is an interesting case for life-saving pharmaceuticals because if the pharmaceutical is controlled by a monopolist or an oligopoly, they know that you are willing to pay as much as possible for your life. But they can only charge one price for a drug, so they calculate the optimal price which some consumers cannot afford. Finding how many people are not able to afford medication goes into the income distribution of a nation.


This is why markets have regulations, mainly to get rid of monopolies and to increase competition, lowering the price.


You could also test a mixed socialist-capitalist healthcare market but that is for another time.

The problem with this model is the same one that plagues every marginalist model: it does not take into account production costs and instead imagines a sort of "natural endowment" economy. When you realize that goods must be produced before they can be offered for sale, and that producers will leave a certain market for greener pastures if that line of business is yielding a below-average rate of profit (and in fact, producers will be forced to leave a certain market if the going price for a good does not amount to a "reproduction" cost for that good for a particular producer), you arrive at the conclusion discovered by the classical economists such as Adam Smith: that the market price for any good will converge on its typical cost of production + an average rate of profit. The only effect that buyer sentiment has is to determine how many rockets will be bought at that price, and thus how many rockets will be produced. The subjective desires of the buyers and their sense of how much the rockets are "worth" to them have nothing whatsoever to do with the market price of the rockets in the long run.

This illustrates some fundamental properties of markets quite well. Maybe you could make a video on barter exchange some time in the near future. Also what I think would be much more interesting than merely examining how goods are exchanged is examining how they are produced as well.
Further I have to say I take issue with your use of the word “value”. This might be a well established term in bourgeois economics but the concept of “value” being created through exchange is arguably laughable. In the model, clearly both parties are happy with the trade, you could say the overall satisfaction increases. No additional value is being created though. Literally nothing about the good changes besides its owner. If we define value solely as a measure of what was needed to produce the good, the value of the good is constant if the “cost” of production doesn’t change and with perfect knowledge of it by every party it would be equal to the average price of the good over time on the market.
Nonetheless a very qualitatively impressive video.

But intervening into the market with regulations or redistributions would subsidise the incapable and punish the capable, which removes extremely important features of any market: motivation and as a consequence thereof the ability to evolve. Every provider right of the equilibrium NEEDS to vanish from the market as some kind of "creative destruction". And if you eliminate this market cleansing, you would introduce a negative selection. Bad strategy, bad behavior, bad prices, bad quality and so on would survive and spread and cost much, much more wealth than any market cleansing of 1 or 2 percent of the providers per year. And goods like food or labour are no exceptions. Whats the reason that food is still a rare good in third world countries? Because states intervene with free supplies and regional farmers go broke. Whats the reason, that more and more people are unemployed? Because the states intervene by collecting taxes and pass the minimum wage law, which raises the labour cost. That goes on and on.

You are right at the end of the video, there's much more we are not taking into account, like producing costs, the costs of of saving money which makes possible to reduce the producing costs in the future by R&D, not all the products having objectively the same perceived quality (not necessarily talking about the different price you are willing to pay to a common product, but about the differentiation of products between brands or even products we call replaceable, like margarine and butter), etc. . Free markets are not perfect but it's the best way to let an economy to organize itself.

For example, the producers that do not fit the buyers prices' expectatives will be expelled from the market. With the intervened economy you showed at the end you've eliminated meritocracy in both sides: the buyers (doesn't matter how much money you've got, which is directly related to the amount of money you are willing to pay, among other factors) and the sellers (doesn't matter how efficient you are at creating products and bringing them to the market, you have insured the sells, your company and your rents).

If you introduced a factor of market's survival (in which you exit producing products if you don't manage to sell anyone after a couple of days) then there would be an interesting market's opportunity for competitors, because there's potentially less sellers to sell and the same buyers demand.

Intervening markets are inefficient in he way of showing real prices also. That's the reason of the recent housing bubble, for example. Many, many variables not taking in count to avoid any possibility to choose an intervened economy as the best option. The best simulation you've actually got is real life and we know how liberal markets and socialist countries go on. It's even more evident than natural selection in which maybe a computer simulation may be needed for educational purposes.

Hey great content ;)
I still have some some hopefully constructive criticism.
First of all, it is extremely difficult, to explain very complex topics on oversimplified examples. The problems with the explained market are all the assumption on that model. In oder for this to relliably work one has to be a computer without emotional outbursts, without feelings, always calculating the best offer to maximize a certain goal. In this example the goal is to maximize value ( well money, not exactly value ). And that's where the problem lies. If I wanted to code up an agent to maximize some value function, this model has a lot going for it, but for human beings this is disasterous. Almost all assumptions are not true in really almost any Market. Perfect information is never possible. Also for this to be fair, everybody should at least start of with an equal amount of value ( money in this system ), but the divide between rich and poor only widens as capitalism progresses. So to just try to regulate it will not work because the problem is not some faults in capitalism but capitalism itself.
So to conclude, I think these kinds of oversimplifications are more dangerous than helpful because they give a false sense of understanding. Although you made a good effort in exlaining why this model might not work. I just think you did not go far enough explaining the riscs attached to this model.

Ps: Ever thaught about why we have patents for everything? This is also just a weird regulation or patch on the system called capitalism in order to not break down. But it makes no sense to implement such a thing. Why should we lock out other people from our ideas and creations? I belive if we were able to share our resources, like you do with this video, we humans would be a lot farther as a species. Not to mention all the nonesensical bureaucratic work that could be safed.

Awesome video! One thing I didn't really internalize before watching this is how the market empowers the smaller group between the buyers and the sellers (which you mention around 4:50). In a situation where there are more sellers than buyers - say, the labor market, where prospective employees outnumber prospective employers - the buyers (in this case, employers) are empowered. In the opposite situation, like the internet service market (or the majority of markets in general), the sellers are empowered. This strikes me as fundamentally anti-democratic: in a democracy, the larger group wields more power, while in a market, the smaller group wields more power. To me, this seems like an important drawback of a market system -- minority rule. Maybe it's worth mentioning as a drawback of a market system, but perhaps it's too ideological of an argument for a video like this.

the subjective theory of value has a massive hole that nobody (within the Liberal framework) really notices.

when supply and demand are in equilibrium, what sets the value of the product?
there is some kind of abstract, inherent value to commodities, based on the value of the labor required to manufacture the item, combined with the value of the resources contained within the item.
there is use value (the buyer's "maximum price" reflects this) and exchange value, but there is also some inherent, baked-in value within the commodity itself.

the labor theory of value is the only theory that acknowledges this form of value, but unfortunately, the LTV brings up some questions about "fairness" within commodity production and employee compensation, so it had to be ditched by mainstream economists, and they found the subjective theory of value which is a very poor substitute that can't even really explain how things get their price in an idealized market (let alone real-world markets), aside from "well they wanted it real bad"

I was brought here by 3Blue1Brown, and I gotta say, I really like this video! Though I would personally emphasize the limitations of the model a bit more: for one, accurate consumer information is really difficult and time-consuming to obtain. To pick a concrete example, if you’re conscious of environmental problems, you may want to buy products that don’t harm the environment as much as others. Many larger companies, of course, have by now noticed that marketing their products in an environmentally friendly way stimulates demand for their products, but because actually changing their production process would mean cutting profits, they instead resort to marketing campaigns, fake labels (the Rountable of Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is a great example of this), etc. to give off the impression that they are working towards reducing environmental impact without changing anything. This works because an overwhelming majority of people doesn’t have the capacities to check anyway. Additionally, production chains are often very long, so it’s not at all easy to really trace everything back. Being informed about this stuff in this day and age means spending multiple hours a day researching those things – hours that very few people actually have to spare.

And that’s assuming that economic decisions are rational to begin with, when they are frequently much more emotion-based (of course, there’s no clear way to distinguish rational actions from emotion-based ones, but you get the idea). Advertisement is specifically designed to invoke these emotional responses, after all. If these decisions were in fact largely rational, however, we would still have the problem that most people don’t have the capacities to make these rational decisions to begin with because it takes a ridiculous amount of work to compare prices, the features of a product, etc. and buy the one best suiting the individual’s need based on that.

Furthermore, in many cases, economic transactions are really not voluntary. Most people don’t spend a lot of money on pointless luxuries, but on things they need to survive and take part in social life. If you can’t get any food, you starve. If you don’t have access to the Internet at home, your employment opportunities will be drastically reduced. If you don’t have a job, you can’t really earn the money to afford these things. The standard example that we see pretty much everywhere in Western countries are the ludicrous costs of housing in major cities and the large amount of empty homes that are empty purely for speculatory reasons, all while homelessness is incredibly high. A lot of the time, there is very little influence on behalf of consumers in price formation. Yes, maybe the some other competitor will then offer them a better deal, but free competition is a pretty big ideal to start with. Starting a business requires a good amount of capital to begin with, and even disregarding the hurdles of entry, when a market is largely dominated by a few suppliers, there’s a huge incentive to just charge a more or less equal price for a product. Going ahead and lowering prices if it’s possible to reduce production costs is a risky move, especially since profit rates have a tendency to fall over time anyway. On the macroeconomic scale, prices are often anything but flexible – standard mark-up pricing will generally suffice. Just because something works on, say, a bazaar doesn’t mean it can be generalized accurately into the world of macroeconomics.

This is far from a comprehensive coverage of the limitations of this model, but I just wanted to throw it out there and possibly inspire discussion. Have a nice day, dear reader who read this far! :)
